reasoning: The critique targets one load-bearing sub-argument in the paper’s broader case: that (difference-making) bounded views with separate aggregation are “fussy” because vanishingly small bads ruin mostly-great status. That point matters to the paper’s taxonomy of fussy vs easygoing views, but the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion also rests on other, independent pillars (multiplicative fragility, linear/unbounded arguments, etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique’s main thrust—that the dramatic ‘1 in 10^22’ cliff is highly dependent on how the bound and saturation curve are parameterized, and in particular on assuming common-sense utopia sits around ~50% of the positive bound—is a real weakness for that illustrative calculation, so it moderately weakens the attacked claim. However it doesn’t fully refute the paper’s broader claim that many plausible separate-aggregation bounded views still end up very sensitive to bads; it mostly shows the extremity of the quantitative example isn’t robust. Most of what it says is directionally correct (sensitivity depends on the shape/normalization of the bounding function and where common-sense utopia lies relative to the upper bound), though it’s somewhat underspecified and arguably under-engages with the paper’s own normalization choices (best feasible fixed at 1, mostly-great at 0.5). Clear, focused, and low on fluff.
title: Bounded view fussiness depends heavily on saturation curve and bound calibration
